summary.long: Exodus is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who went to Egypt with Jacob, each with his family:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi and Judah;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Issachar, Zebulun and Benjamin;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dan and Naphtali; Gad and Asher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Jacob numbered seventy in all; Joseph was already in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joseph and all his brothers and all that generation died,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the Israelites were exceedingly fruitful; they multiplied greatly, increased in numbers and became so numerous that the land was filled with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a new king, to whom Joseph meant nothing, came to power in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Look,’ he said to his people, ‘the Israelites have become far too numerous for us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, we must deal shrewdly with them or they will become even more numerous and, if war breaks out, will join our enemies, fight against us and leave the country.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they put slave masters over them to oppress them with forced labour, and they built Pithom and Rameses as store cities for Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the more they were oppressed, the more they multiplied and spread; so the Egyptians came to dread the Israelites
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and worked them ruthlessly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They made their lives bitter with harsh labour in brick and mortar and with all kinds of work in the fields; in all their harsh labour, the Egyptians worked them ruthlessly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt said to the Hebrew midwives, whose names were Shiphrah and Puah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘When you are helping the Hebrew women during childbirth on the delivery stool, if you see that the baby is a boy, kill him; but if it is a girl, let her live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The midwives, however, feared God and did not do what the king of Egypt had told them to do; they let the boys live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Egypt summoned the midwives and asked them, ‘Why have you done this? Why have you let the boys live?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The midwives answered Pharaoh, ‘Hebrew women are not like Egyptian women; they are vigorous and give birth before the midwives arrive.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God was kind to the midwives and the people increased and became even more numerous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And because the midwives feared God, he gave them families of their own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh gave this order to all his people: ‘Every Hebrew boy that is born you must throw into the Nile, but let every girl live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a man of the tribe of Levi married a Levite woman,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and she became pregnant and gave birth to a son. When she saw that he was a fine child, she hid him for three months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when she could hide him no longer, she got a papyrus basket for him and coated it with tar and pitch. Then she placed the child in it and put it among the reeds along the bank of the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sister stood at a distance to see what would happen to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh’s daughter went down to the Nile to bathe, and her attendants were walking along the river-bank. She saw the basket among the reeds and sent her female slave to get it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She opened it and saw the baby. He was crying, and she felt sorry for him. ‘This is one of the Hebrew babies,’ she said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his sister asked Pharaoh’s daughter, ‘Shall I go and get one of the Hebrew women to nurse the baby for you?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Yes, go,’ she answered. So the girl went and got the baby’s mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, ‘Take this baby and nurse him for me, and I will pay you.’ So the woman took the baby and nursed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the child grew older, she took him to Pharaoh’s daughter and he became her son. She named him Moses, saying, ‘I drew him out of the water.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day, after Moses had grown up, he went out to where his own people were and watched them at their hard labour. He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Looking this way and that and seeing no one, he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day he went out and saw two Hebrews fighting. He asked the one in the wrong, ‘Why are you hitting your fellow Hebrew?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man said, ‘Who made you ruler and judge over us? Are you thinking of killing me as you killed the Egyptian?’ Then Moses was afraid and thought, ‘What I did must have become known.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh heard of this, he tried to kill Moses, but Moses fled from Pharaoh and went to live in Midian, where he sat down by a well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a priest of Midian had seven daughters, and they came to draw water and fill the troughs to water their father’s flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some shepherds came along and drove them away, but Moses got up and came to their rescue and watered their flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the girls returned to Reuel their father, he asked them, ‘Why have you returned so early today?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered, ‘An Egyptian rescued us from the shepherds. He even drew water for us and watered the flock.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘And where is he?’ Reuel asked his daughters. ‘Why did you leave him? Invite him to have something to eat.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses agreed to stay with the man, who gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses in marriage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zipporah gave birth to a son, and Moses named him Gershom, saying, ‘I have become a foreigner in a foreign land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During that long period, the king of Egypt died. The Israelites groaned in their slavery and cried out, and their cry for help because of their slavery went up to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God heard their groaning and he remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac and with Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God looked on the Israelites and was concerned about them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Moses was tending the flock of Jethro his father-in-law, the priest of Midian, and he led the flock to the far side of the wilderness and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There the angel of the Lord appeared to him in flames of fire from within a bush. Moses saw that though the bush was on fire it did not burn up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses thought, ‘I will go over and see this strange sight – why the bush does not burn up.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the Lord saw that he had gone over to look, God called to him from within the bush, ‘Moses! Moses!’
And Moses said, ‘Here I am.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: ‘Do not come any closer,’ God said. ‘Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then he said, ‘I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.’ At this, Moses hid his face, because he was afraid to look at God.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The Lord said, ‘I have indeed seen the misery of my people in Egypt. I have heard them crying out because of their slave drivers, and I am concerned about their suffering.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So I have come down to rescue them from the hand of the Egyptians and to bring them up out of that land into a good and spacious land, a land flowing with milk and honey – the home of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: And now the cry of the Israelites has reached me, and I have seen the way the Egyptians are oppressing them.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So now, go. I am sending you to Pharaoh to bring my people the Israelites out of Egypt.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: But Moses said to God, ‘Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and bring the Israelites out of Egypt?’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: And God said, ‘I will be with you. And this will be the sign to you that it is I who have sent you: when you have brought the people out of Egypt, you will worship God on this mountain.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Moses said to God, ‘Suppose I go to the Israelites and say to them, “The God of your fathers has sent me to you,” and they ask me, “What is his name?” Then what shall I tell them?’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God said to Moses, ‘I am who I am. This is what you are to say to the Israelites: “I am has sent me to you.”’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
God also said to Moses, ‘Say to the Israelites, “The Lord, the God of your fathers – the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob – has sent me to you.”
‘This is my name for ever,
    the name you shall call me
    from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: ‘Go, assemble the elders of Israel and say to them, “The Lord, the God of your fathers – the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob – appeared to me and said: I have watched over you and have seen what has been done to you in Egypt.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: And I have promised to bring you up out of your misery in Egypt into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites – a land flowing with milk and honey.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: ‘The elders of Israel will listen to you. Then you and the elders are to go to the king of Egypt and say to him, “The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us. Let us take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go unless a mighty hand compels him.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So I will stretch out my hand and strike the Egyptians with all the wonders that I will perform among them. After that, he will let you go.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: ‘And I will make the Egyptians favourably disposed towards this people, so that when you leave you will not go empty-handed.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Every woman is to ask her neighbour and any woman living in her house for articles of silver and gold and for clothing, which you will put on your sons and daughters. And so you will plunder the Egyptians.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Moses answered, ‘What if they do not believe me or listen to me and say, “The Lord did not appear to you”?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the Lord said to him, ‘What is that in your hand?’
‘A staff,’ he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said, ‘Throw it on the ground.’
Moses threw it on the ground and it became a snake, and he ran from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to him, ‘Reach out your hand and take it by the tail.’ So Moses reached out and took hold of the snake and it turned back into a staff in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This,’ said the Lord, ‘is so that they may believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers – the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob – has appeared to you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said, ‘Put your hand inside your cloak.’ So Moses put his hand into his cloak, and when he took it out, the skin was leprous – it had become as white as snow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Now put it back into your cloak,’ he said. So Moses put his hand back into his cloak, and when he took it out, it was restored, like the rest of his flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said, ‘If they do not believe you or pay attention to the first sign, they may believe the second.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if they do not believe these two signs or listen to you, take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground. The water you take from the river will become blood on the ground.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to the Lord, ‘Pardon your servant, Lord. I have never been eloquent, neither in the past nor since you have spoken to your servant. I am slow of speech and tongue.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, ‘Who gave human beings their mouths? Who makes them deaf or mute? Who gives them sight or makes them blind? Is it not I, the Lord?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go; I will help you speak and will teach you what to say.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said, ‘Pardon your servant, Lord. Please send someone else.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord’s anger burned against Moses and he said, ‘What about your brother, Aaron the Levite? I know he can speak well. He is already on his way to meet you, and he will be glad to see you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall speak to him and put words in his mouth; I will help both of you speak and will teach you what to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will speak to the people for you, and it will be as if he were your mouth and as if you were God to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But take this staff in your hand so that you can perform the signs with it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moses went back to Jethro his father-in-law and said to him, ‘Let me return to my own people in Egypt to see if any of them are still alive.’
Jethro said, ‘Go, and I wish you well.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord had said to Moses in Midian, ‘Go back to Egypt, for all those who wanted to kill you are dead.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses took his wife and sons, put them on a donkey and started back to Egypt. And he took the staff of God in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, ‘When you return to Egypt, see that you perform before Pharaoh all the wonders I have given you the power to do. But I will harden his heart so that he will not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then say to Pharaoh, “This is what the Lord says: Israel is my firstborn son,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I told you, ‘Let my son go, so that he may worship me.’ But you refused to let him go; so I will kill your firstborn son.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At a lodging place on the way, the Lord met Moses and was about to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zipporah took a flint knife, cut off her son’s foreskin and touched Moses’ feet with it. ‘Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me,’ she said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord let him alone. (At that time she said ‘bridegroom of blood’, referring to circumcision.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Aaron, ‘Go into the wilderness to meet Moses.’ So he met Moses at the mountain of God and kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told Aaron everything the Lord had sent him to say, and also about all the signs he had commanded him to perform.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron brought together all the elders of the Israelites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Aaron told them everything the Lord had said to Moses. He also performed the signs before the people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they believed. And when they heard that the Lord was concerned about them and had seen their misery, they bowed down and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterwards Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: “Let my people go, so that they may hold a festival to me in the wilderness.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, ‘Who is the Lord, that I should obey him and let Israel go? I do not know the Lord and I will not let Israel go.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said, ‘The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Now let us take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God, or he may strike us with plagues or with the sword.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king of Egypt said, ‘Moses and Aaron, why are you taking the people away from their labour? Get back to your work!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said, ‘Look, the people of the land are now numerous, and you are stopping them from working.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day Pharaoh gave this order to the slave drivers and overseers in charge of the people:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You are no longer to supply the people with straw for making bricks; let them go and gather their own straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But require them to make the same number of bricks as before; don’t reduce the quota. They are lazy; that is why they are crying out, “Let us go and sacrifice to our God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make the work harder for the people so that they keep working and pay no attention to lies.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the slave drivers and the overseers went out and said to the people, ‘This is what Pharaoh says: “I will not give you any more straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go and get your own straw wherever you can find it, but your work will not be reduced at all.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people scattered all over Egypt to gather stubble to use for straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The slave drivers kept pressing them, saying, ‘Complete the work required of you for each day, just as when you had straw.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Pharaoh’s slave drivers beat the Israelite overseers they had appointed, demanding, ‘Why haven’t you met your quota of bricks yesterday or today, as before?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Israelite overseers went and appealed to Pharaoh: ‘Why have you treated your servants this way?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servants are given no straw, yet we are told, “Make bricks!” Your servants are being beaten, but the fault is with your own people.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, ‘Lazy, that’s what you are – lazy! That is why you keep saying, “Let us go and sacrifice to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now get to work. You will not be given any straw, yet you must produce your full quota of bricks.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelite overseers realised they were in trouble when they were told, ‘You are not to reduce the number of bricks required of you for each day.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they left Pharaoh, they found Moses and Aaron waiting to meet them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they said, ‘May the Lord look on you and judge you! You have made us obnoxious to Pharaoh and his officials and have put a sword in their hand to kill us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses returned to the Lord and said, ‘Why, Lord, why have you brought trouble on this people? Is this why you sent me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ever since I went to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has brought trouble on this people, and you have not rescued your people at all.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh: because of my mighty hand he will let them go; because of my mighty hand he will drive them out of his country.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God also said to Moses, ‘I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac and to Jacob as God Almighty, but by my name the Lord I did not make myself known to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also established my covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, where they resided as foreigners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, I have heard the groaning of the Israelites, whom the Egyptians are enslaving, and I have remembered my covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Therefore, say to the Israelites: “I am the Lord, and I will bring you out from under the yoke of the Egyptians. I will free you from being slaves to them, and I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with mighty acts of judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take you as my own people, and I will be your God. Then you will know that I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from under the yoke of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will bring you to the land I swore with uplifted hand to give to Abraham, to Isaac and to Jacob. I will give it to you as a possession. I am the Lord.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses reported this to the Israelites, but they did not listen to him because of their discouragement and harsh labour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Go, tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the Israelites go out of his country.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said to the Lord, ‘If the Israelites will not listen to me, why would Pharaoh listen to me, since I speak with faltering lips?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron about the Israelites and Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he commanded them to bring the Israelites out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the heads of their families:
The sons of Reuben the firstborn son of Israel were Hanok and Pallu, Hezron and Karmi. These were the clans of Reuben.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman. These were the clans of Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the names of the sons of Levi according to their records: Gershon, Kohath and Merari. Levi lived 137 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Gershon, by clans, were Libni and Shimei.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi.
These were the clans of Levi according to their records.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amram married his father’s sister Jochebed, who bore him Aaron and Moses. Amram lived 137 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg and Zikri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan and Sithri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron married Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon, and she bore him Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah and Abiasaph. These were the Korahite clans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eleazar son of Aaron married one of the daughters of Putiel, and she bore him Phinehas.
These were the heads of the Levite families, clan by clan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was this Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, ‘Bring the Israelites out of Egypt by their divisions.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were the ones who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt about bringing the Israelites out of Egypt – this same Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when the Lord spoke to Moses in Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said to him, ‘I am the Lord. Tell Pharaoh king of Egypt everything I tell you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said to the Lord, ‘Since I speak with faltering lips, why would Pharaoh listen to me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘See, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to say everything I command you, and your brother Aaron is to tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites go out of his country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and though I multiply my signs and wonders in Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he will not listen to you. Then I will lay my hand on Egypt and with mighty acts of judgment I will bring out my divisions, my people the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I stretch out my hand against Egypt and bring the Israelites out of it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord commanded them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three when they spoke to Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘When Pharaoh says to you, “Perform a miracle,” then say to Aaron, “Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh,” and it will become a snake.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did just as the Lord commanded. Aaron threw his staff down in front of Pharaoh and his officials, and it became a snake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh then summoned the wise men and sorcerers, and the Egyptian magicians also did the same things by their secret arts:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: each one threw down his staff and it became a snake. But Aaron’s staff swallowed up their staffs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet Pharaoh’s heart became hard and he would not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Pharaoh’s heart is unyielding; he refuses to let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning as he goes out to the river. Confront him on the bank of the Nile, and take in your hand the staff that was changed into a snake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then say to him, “The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has sent me to say to you: let my people go, so that they may worship me in the wilderness. But until now you have not listened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: by this you will know that I am the Lord: with the staff that is in my hand I will strike the water of the Nile, and it will be changed into blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fish in the Nile will die, and the river will stink; the Egyptians will not be able to drink its water.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, ‘Tell Aaron, “Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt – over the streams and canals, over the ponds and all the reservoirs – and they will turn to blood.” Blood will be everywhere in Egypt, even in vessels of wood and stone.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord had commanded. He raised his staff in the presence of Pharaoh and his officials and struck the water of the Nile, and all the water was changed into blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fish in the Nile died, and the river smelled so bad that the Egyptians could not drink its water. Blood was everywhere in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Egyptian magicians did the same things by their secret arts, and Pharaoh’s heart became hard; he would not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, he turned and went into his palace, and did not take even this to heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the Egyptians dug along the Nile to get drinking water, because they could not drink the water of the river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven days passed after the Lord struck the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Go to Pharaoh and say to him, “This is what the Lord says: let my people go, so that they may worship me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you refuse to let them go, I will send a plague of frogs on your whole country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Nile will teem with frogs. They will come up into your palace and your bedroom and onto your bed, into the houses of your officials and on your people, and into your ovens and kneading troughs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The frogs will come up on you and your people and all your officials.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Tell Aaron, “Stretch out your hand with your staff over the streams and canals and ponds, and make frogs come up on the land of Egypt.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the magicians did the same things by their secret arts; they also made frogs come up on the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, ‘Pray to the Lord to take the frogs away from me and my people, and I will let your people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to Pharaoh, ‘I leave to you the honour of setting the time for me to pray for you and your officials and your people that you and your houses may be rid of the frogs, except for those that remain in the Nile.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Tomorrow,’ Pharaoh said.
Moses replied, ‘It will be as you say, so that you may know there is no one like the Lord our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The frogs will leave you and your houses, your officials and your people; they will remain only in the Nile.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Moses and Aaron left Pharaoh, Moses cried out to the Lord about the frogs he had brought on Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord did what Moses asked. The frogs died in the houses, in the courtyards and in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were piled into heaps, and the land reeked of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he hardened his heart and would not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Tell Aaron, “Stretch out your staff and strike the dust of the ground,” and throughout the land of Egypt the dust will become gnats.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They did this, and when Aaron stretched out his hand with the staff and struck the dust of the ground, gnats came on people and animals. All the dust throughout the land of Egypt became gnats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But when the magicians tried to produce gnats by their secret arts, they could not.
Since the gnats were on people and animals everywhere,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the magicians said to Pharaoh, ‘This is the finger of God.’ But Pharaoh’s heart was hard and he would not listen, just as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Get up early in the morning and confront Pharaoh as he goes to the river and say to him, “This is what the Lord says: let my people go, so that they may worship me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you do not let my people go, I will send swarms of flies on you and your officials, on your people and into your houses. The houses of the Egyptians will be full of flies; even the ground will be covered with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘“But on that day I will deal differently with the land of Goshen, where my people live; no swarms of flies will be there, so that you will know that I, the Lord, am in this land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make a distinction between my people and your people. This sign will occur tomorrow.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord did this. Dense swarms of flies poured into Pharaoh’s palace and into the houses of his officials; throughout Egypt the land was ruined by the flies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, ‘Go, sacrifice to your God here in the land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said, ‘That would not be right. The sacrifices we offer the Lord our God would be detestable to the Egyptians. And if we offer sacrifices that are detestable in their eyes, will they not stone us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We must take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God, as he commands us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, ‘I will let you go to offer sacrifices to the Lord your God in the wilderness, but you must not go very far. Now pray for me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses answered, ‘As soon as I leave you, I will pray to the Lord, and tomorrow the flies will leave Pharaoh and his officials and his people. Only let Pharaoh be sure that he does not act deceitfully again by not letting the people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord did what Moses asked. The flies left Pharaoh and his officials and his people; not a fly remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But this time also Pharaoh hardened his heart and would not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Go to Pharaoh and say to him, “This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: ‘Let my people go, so that they may worship me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them back,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the hand of the Lord will bring a terrible plague on your livestock in the field – on your horses, donkeys and camels and on your cattle, sheep and goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and that of Egypt, so that no animal belonging to the Israelites will die.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord set a time and said, ‘Tomorrow the Lord will do this in the land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the next day the Lord did it: all the livestock of the Egyptians died, but not one animal belonging to the Israelites died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh investigated and found that not even one of the animals of the Israelites had died. Yet his heart was unyielding and he would not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, ‘Take handfuls of soot from a furnace and let Moses toss it into the air in the presence of Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will become fine dust over the whole land of Egypt, and festering boils will break out on people and animals throughout the land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took soot from a furnace and stood before Pharaoh. Moses tossed it into the air, and festering boils broke out on people and animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils that were on them and on all the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart and he would not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the Lord had said to Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Get up early in the morning, confront Pharaoh and say to him, “This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: let my people go, so that they may worship me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: or this time I will send the full force of my plagues against you and against your officials and your people, so you may know that there is no one like me in all the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For by now I could have stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with a plague that would have wiped you off the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I have raised you up for this very purpose, that I might show you my power and that my name might be proclaimed in all the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You still set yourself against my people and will not let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, at this time tomorrow I will send the worst hailstorm that has ever fallen on Egypt, from the day it was founded till now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give an order now to bring your livestock and everything you have in the field to a place of shelter, because the hail will fall on every person and animal that has not been brought in and is still out in the field, and they will die.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those officials of Pharaoh who feared the word of the Lord hurried to bring their slaves and their livestock inside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But those who ignored the word of the Lord left their slaves and livestock in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Stretch out your hand towards the sky so that hail will fall all over Egypt – on people and animals and on everything growing in the fields of Egypt.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses stretched out his staff towards the sky, the Lord sent thunder and hail, and lightning flashed down to the ground. So the Lord rained hail on the land of Egypt;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: hail fell and lightning flashed back and forth. It was the worst storm in all the land of Egypt since it had become a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Throughout Egypt hail struck everything in the fields – both people and animals; it beat down everything growing in the fields and stripped every tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The only place it did not hail was the land of Goshen, where the Israelites were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron. ‘This time I have sinned,’ he said to them. ‘The Lord is in the right, and I and my people are in the wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pray to the Lord, for we have had enough thunder and hail. I will let you go; you don’t have to stay any longer.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses replied, ‘When I have gone out of the city, I will spread out my hands in prayer to the Lord. The thunder will stop and there will be no more hail, so you may know that the earth is the Lord’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I know that you and your officials still do not fear the Lord God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The flax and barley were destroyed, since the barley was in the ear and the flax was in bloom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wheat and spelt, however, were not destroyed, because they ripen later.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses left Pharaoh and went out of the city. He spread out his hands towards the Lord; the thunder and hail stopped, and the rain no longer poured down on the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh saw that the rain and hail and thunder had stopped, he sinned again: he and his officials hardened their hearts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh’s heart was hard and he would not let the Israelites go, just as the Lord had said through Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart and the hearts of his officials so that I may perform these signs of mine among them
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that you may tell your children and grandchildren how I dealt harshly with the Egyptians and how I performed my signs among them, and that you may know that I am the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said to him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: “How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go, so that they may worship me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you refuse to let them go, I will bring locusts into your country tomorrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will cover the face of the ground so that it cannot be seen. They will devour what little you have left after the hail, including every tree that is growing in your fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will fill your houses and those of all your officials and all the Egyptians – something neither your parents nor your ancestors have ever seen from the day they settled in this land till now.”’ Then Moses turned and left Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s officials said to him, ‘How long will this man be a snare to us? Let the people go, so that they may worship the Lord their God. Do you not yet realise that Egypt is ruined?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh. ‘Go, worship the Lord your God,’ he said. ‘But tell me who will be going.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses answered, ‘We will go with our young and our old, with our sons and our daughters, and with our flocks and herds, because we are to celebrate a festival to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, ‘The Lord be with you – if I let you go, along with your women and children! Clearly you are bent on evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No! Let only the men go and worship the Lord, since that’s what you have been asking for.’ Then Moses and Aaron were driven out of Pharaoh’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, ‘Stretch out your hand over Egypt so that locusts swarm over the land and devour everything growing in the fields, everything left by the hail.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his staff over Egypt, and the Lord made an east wind blow across the land all that day and all that night. By morning the wind had brought the locusts;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they invaded all Egypt and settled down in every area of the country in great numbers. Never before had there been such a plague of locusts, nor will there ever be again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They covered all the ground until it was black. They devoured all that was left after the hail – everything growing in the fields and the fruit on the trees. Nothing green remained on tree or plant in all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh quickly summoned Moses and Aaron and said, ‘I have sinned against the Lord your God and against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now forgive my sin once more and pray to the Lord your God to take this deadly plague away from me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses then left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord changed the wind to a very strong west wind, which caught up the locusts and carried them into the Red Sea. Not a locust was left anywhere in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he would not let the Israelites go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Stretch out your hand towards the sky so that darkness spreads over Egypt – darkness that can be felt.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his hand towards the sky, and total darkness covered all Egypt for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one could see anyone else or move about for three days. Yet all the Israelites had light in the places where they lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and said, ‘Go, worship the Lord. Even your women and children may go with you; only leave your flocks and herds behind.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said, ‘You must allow us to have sacrifices and burnt offerings to present to the Lord our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our livestock too must go with us; not a hoof is to be left behind. We have to use some of them in worshipping the Lord our God, and until we get there we will not know what we are to use to worship the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he was not willing to let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Moses, ‘Get out of my sight! Make sure you do not appear before me again! The day you see my face you will die.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Just as you say,’ Moses replied. ‘I will never appear before you again.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord said to Moses, ‘I will bring one more plague on Pharaoh and on Egypt. After that, he will let you go from here, and when he does, he will drive you out completely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the people that men and women alike are to ask their neighbours for articles of silver and gold.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The Lord made the Egyptians favourably disposed towards the people, and Moses himself was highly regarded in Egypt by Pharaoh’s officials and by the people.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses said, ‘This is what the Lord says: “About midnight I will go throughout Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every firstborn son in Egypt will die, from the firstborn son of Pharaoh, who sits on the throne, to the firstborn son of the female slave, who is at her hand mill, and all the firstborn of the cattle as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There will be loud wailing throughout Egypt – worse than there has ever been or ever will be again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But among the Israelites not a dog will bark at any person or animal.” Then you will know that the Lord makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these officials of yours will come to me, bowing down before me and saying, “Go, you and all the people who follow you!” After that I will leave.’ Then Moses, hot with anger, left Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord had said to Moses, ‘Pharaoh will refuse to listen to you – so that my wonders may be multiplied in Egypt.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron performed all these wonders before Pharaoh, but the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he would not let the Israelites go out of his country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron in Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This month is to be for you the first month, the first month of your year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the whole community of Israel that on the tenth day of this month each man is to take a lamb for his family, one for each household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If any household is too small for a whole lamb, they must share one with their nearest neighbour, having taken into account the number of people there are. You are to determine the amount of lamb needed in accordance with what each person will eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The animals you choose must be year-old males without defect, and you may take them from the sheep or the goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take care of them until the fourteenth day of the month, when all the members of the community of Israel must slaughter them at twilight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they are to take some of the blood and put it on the sides and tops of the door-frames of the houses where they eat the lambs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same night they are to eat the meat roasted over the fire, along with bitter herbs, and bread made without yeast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not eat the meat raw or boiled in water, but roast it over a fire – with the head, legs and internal organs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not leave any of it till morning; if some is left till morning, you must burn it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how you are to eat it: with your cloak tucked into your belt, your sandals on your feet and your staff in your hand. Eat it in haste; it is the Lord’s Passover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘On that same night I will pass through Egypt and strike down every firstborn of both people and animals, and I will bring judgment on all the gods of Egypt. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The blood will be a sign for you on the houses where you are, and when I see the blood, I will pass over you. No destructive plague will touch you when I strike Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is a day you are to commemorate; for the generations to come you shall celebrate it as a festival to the Lord – a lasting ordinance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days you are to eat bread made without yeast. On the first day remove the yeast from your houses, for whoever eats anything with yeast in it from the first day until the seventh must be cut off from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day hold a sacred assembly, and another one on the seventh day. Do no work at all on these days, except to prepare food for everyone to eat; that is all you may do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread, because it was on this very day that I brought your divisions out of Egypt. Celebrate this day as a lasting ordinance for the generations to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first month you are to eat bread made without yeast, from the evening of the fourteenth day until the evening of the twenty-first day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days no yeast is to be found in your houses. And anyone, whether foreigner or native-born, who eats anything with yeast in it must be cut off from the community of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eat nothing made with yeast. Wherever you live, you must eat unleavened bread.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses summoned all the elders of Israel and said to them, ‘Go at once and select the animals for your families and slaughter the Passover lamb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take a bunch of hyssop, dip it into the blood in the basin and put some of the blood on the top and on both sides of the door-frame. None of you shall go out of the door of your house until morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord goes through the land to strike down the Egyptians, he will see the blood on the top and sides of the door-frame and will pass over that doorway, and he will not permit the destroyer to enter your houses and strike you down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Obey these instructions as a lasting ordinance for you and your descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you enter the land that the Lord will give you as he promised, observe this ceremony.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when your children ask you, “What does this ceremony mean to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then tell them, “It is the Passover sacrifice to the Lord, who passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt and spared our homes when he struck down the Egyptians.”’ Then the people bowed down and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites did just what the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At midnight the Lord struck down all the firstborn in Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh, who sat on the throne, to the firstborn of the prisoner, who was in the dungeon, and the firstborn of all the livestock as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh and all his officials and all the Egyptians got up during the night, and there was loud wailing in Egypt, for there was not a house without someone dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, ‘Up! Leave my people, you and the Israelites! Go, worship the Lord as you have requested.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take your flocks and herds, as you have said, and go. And also bless me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians urged the people to hurry and leave the country. ‘For otherwise,’ they said, ‘we will all die!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people took their dough before the yeast was added, and carried it on their shoulders in kneading troughs wrapped in clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites did as Moses instructed and asked the Egyptians for articles of silver and gold and for clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord had made the Egyptians favourably disposed towards the people, and they gave them what they asked for; so they plundered the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites journeyed from Rameses to Sukkoth. There were about six hundred thousand men on foot, besides women and children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many other people went up with them, and also large droves of livestock, both flocks and herds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the dough the Israelites had brought from Egypt, they baked loaves of unleavened bread. The dough was without yeast because they had been driven out of Egypt and did not have time to prepare food for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the length of time the Israelite people lived in Egypt was 430 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of the 430 years, to the very day, all the Lord’s divisions left Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the Lord kept vigil that night to bring them out of Egypt, on this night all the Israelites are to keep vigil to honour the Lord for the generations to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, ‘These are the regulations for the Passover meal:
‘No foreigner may eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any slave you have bought may eat it after you have circumcised him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but a temporary resident or a hired worker may not eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘It must be eaten inside the house; take none of the meat outside the house. Do not break any of the bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole community of Israel must celebrate it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘A foreigner residing among you who wants to celebrate the Lord’s Passover must have all the males in his household circumcised; then he may take part like one born in the land. No uncircumcised male may eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The same law applies both to the native-born and to the foreigner residing among you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Israelites did just what the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And on that very day the Lord brought the Israelites out of Egypt by their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Consecrate to me every firstborn male. The first offspring of every womb among the Israelites belongs to me, whether human or animal.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said to the people, ‘Commemorate this day, the day you came out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery, because the Lord brought you out of it with a mighty hand. Eat nothing containing yeast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today, in the month of Aviv, you are leaving.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord brings you into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Hivites and Jebusites – the land he swore to your ancestors to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey – you are to observe this ceremony in this month:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for seven days eat bread made without yeast and on the seventh day hold a festival to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eat unleavened bread during those seven days; nothing with yeast in it is to be seen among you, nor shall any yeast be seen anywhere within your borders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day tell your son, “I do this because of what the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This observance will be for you like a sign on your hand and a reminder on your forehead that this law of the Lord is to be on your lips. For the Lord brought you out of Egypt with his mighty hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must keep this ordinance at the appointed time year after year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘After the Lord brings you into the land of the Canaanites and gives it to you, as he promised on oath to you and your ancestors,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you are to give over to the Lord the first offspring of every womb. All the firstborn males of your livestock belong to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Redeem with a lamb every firstborn donkey, but if you do not redeem it, break its neck. Redeem every firstborn among your sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘In days to come when your son asks you, “What does this mean?” say to him, “With a mighty hand the Lord brought us out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the Lord killed the firstborn of both people and animals in Egypt. This is why I sacrifice to the Lord the first male offspring of every womb and redeem each of my firstborn sons.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And it will be like a sign on your hand and a symbol on your forehead that the Lord brought us out of Egypt with his mighty hand.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh let the people go, God did not lead them on the road through the Philistine country, though that was shorter. For God said, ‘If they face war, they might change their minds and return to Egypt.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God led the people around by the desert road towards the Red Sea. The Israelites went up out of Egypt ready for battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses took the bones of Joseph with him because Joseph had made the Israelites swear an oath. He had said, ‘God will surely come to your aid, and then you must carry my bones up with you from this place.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After leaving Sukkoth they camped at Etham on the edge of the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By day the Lord went ahead of them in a pillar of cloud to guide them on their way and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so that they could travel by day or night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Neither the pillar of cloud by day nor the pillar of fire by night left its place in front of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Tell the Israelites to turn back and camp near Pi Hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea. They are to camp by the sea, directly opposite Baal Zephon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh will think, “The Israelites are wandering around the land in confusion, hemmed in by the desert.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and he will pursue them. But I will gain glory for myself through Pharaoh and all his army, and the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.’ So the Israelites did this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, Pharaoh and his officials changed their minds about them and said, ‘What have we done? We have let the Israelites go and have lost their services!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he had his chariot made ready and took his army with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took six hundred of the best chariots, along with all the other chariots of Egypt, with officers over all of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, so that he pursued the Israelites, who were marching out boldly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians – all Pharaoh’s horses and chariots, horsemen and troops – pursued the Israelites and overtook them as they camped by the sea near Pi Hahiroth, opposite Baal Zephon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Pharaoh approached, the Israelites looked up, and there were the Egyptians, marching after them. They were terrified and cried out to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Moses, ‘Was it because there were no graves in Egypt that you brought us to the desert to die? What have you done to us by bringing us out of Egypt?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Didn’t we say to you in Egypt, “Leave us alone; let us serve the Egyptians”? It would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the desert!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses answered the people, ‘Do not be afraid. Stand firm and you will see the deliverance the Lord will bring you today. The Egyptians you see today you will never see again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will fight for you; you need only to be still.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Why are you crying out to me? Tell the Israelites to move on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Raise your staff and stretch out your hand over the sea to divide the water so that the Israelites can go through the sea on dry ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they will go in after them. And I will gain glory through Pharaoh and all his army, through his chariots and his horsemen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I gain glory through Pharaoh, his chariots and his horsemen.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of God, who had been travelling in front of Israel’s army, withdrew and went behind them. The pillar of cloud also moved from in front and stood behind them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: coming between the armies of Egypt and Israel. Throughout the night the cloud brought darkness to the one side and light to the other; so neither went near the other all night long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and all that night the Lord drove the sea back with a strong east wind and turned it into dry land. The waters were divided,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Israelites went through the sea on dry ground, with a wall of water on their right and on their left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued them, and all Pharaoh’s horses and chariots and horsemen followed them into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the last watch of the night the Lord looked down from the pillar of fire and cloud at the Egyptian army and threw it into confusion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He jammed the wheels of their chariots so that they had difficulty driving. And the Egyptians said, ‘Let’s get away from the Israelites! The Lord is fighting for them against Egypt.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Stretch out your hand over the sea so that the waters may flow back over the Egyptians and their chariots and horsemen.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and at daybreak the sea went back to its place. The Egyptians were fleeing towards it, and the Lord swept them into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The water flowed back and covered the chariots and horsemen – the entire army of Pharaoh that had followed the Israelites into the sea. Not one of them survived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Israelites went through the sea on dry ground, with a wall of water on their right and on their left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day the Lord saved Israel from the hands of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians lying dead on the shore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the Israelites saw the mighty hand of the Lord displayed against the Egyptians, the people feared the Lord and put their trust in him and in Moses his servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the Lord:
‘I will sing to the Lord,
    for he is highly exalted.
Both horse and driver
    he has hurled into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘The Lord is my strength and my defence;
    he has become my salvation.
He is my God, and I will praise him,
    my father’s God, and I will exalt him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is a warrior;
    the Lord is his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh’s chariots and his army
    he has hurled into the sea.
The best of Pharaoh’s officers
    are drowned in the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The deep waters have covered them;
    they sank to the depths like a stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your right hand, Lord,
    was majestic in power.
Your right hand, Lord,
    shattered the enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘In the greatness of your majesty
    you threw down those who opposed you.
You unleashed your burning anger;
    it consumed them like stubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By the blast of your nostrils
    the waters piled up.
The surging waters stood up like a wall;
    the deep waters congealed in the heart of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The enemy boasted,
    “I will pursue, I will overtake them.
I will divide the spoils;
    I will gorge myself on them.
I will draw my sword
    and my hand will destroy them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you blew with your breath,
    and the sea covered them.
They sank like lead
    in the mighty waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who among the gods
    is like you, Lord?
Who is like you –
    majestic in holiness,
awesome in glory,
    working wonders?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘You stretch out your right hand,
    and the earth swallows your enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In your unfailing love you will lead
    the people you have redeemed.
In your strength you will guide them
    to your holy dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The nations will hear and tremble;
    anguish will grip the people of Philistia.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
terror and dread will fall on them.
By the power of your arm
    they will be as still as a stone –
until your people pass by, Lord,
    until the people you bought pass by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will bring them in and plant them
    on the mountain of your inheritance –
the place, Lord, you made for your dwelling,
    the sanctuary, Lord, your hands established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘The Lord reigns
    for ever and ever.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh’s horses, chariots and horsemen went into the sea, the Lord brought the waters of the sea back over them, but the Israelites walked through the sea on dry ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Miriam the prophet, Aaron’s sister, took a tambourine in her hand, and all the women followed her, with tambourines and dancing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Miriam sang to them:
‘Sing to the Lord,
    for he is highly exalted.
Both horse and driver
    he has hurled into the sea.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses led Israel from the Red Sea and they went into the Desert of Shur. For three days they travelled in the desert without finding water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to Marah, they could not drink its water because it was bitter. (That is why the place is called Marah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people grumbled against Moses, saying, ‘What are we to drink?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moses cried out to the Lord, and the Lord showed him a piece of wood. He threw it into the water, and the water became fit to drink.
There the Lord issued a ruling and instruction for them and put them to the test.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, ‘If you listen carefully to the Lord your God and do what is right in his eyes, if you pay attention to his commands and keep all his decrees, I will not bring on you any of the diseases I brought on the Egyptians, for I am the Lord, who heals you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to Elim, where there were twelve springs and seventy palm trees, and they camped there near the water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole Israelite community set out from Elim and came to the Desert of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after they had come out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the desert the whole community grumbled against Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites said to them, ‘If only we had died by the Lord’s hand in Egypt! There we sat round pots of meat and ate all the food we wanted, but you have brought us out into this desert to starve this entire assembly to death.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘I will rain down bread from heaven for you. The people are to go out each day and gather enough for that day. In this way I will test them and see whether they will follow my instructions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the sixth day they are to prepare what they bring in, and that is to be twice as much as they gather on the other days.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron said to all the Israelites, ‘In the evening you will know that it was the Lord who brought you out of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in the morning you will see the glory of the Lord, because he has heard your grumbling against him. Who are we, that you should grumble against us?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses also said, ‘You will know that it was the Lord when he gives you meat to eat in the evening and all the bread you want in the morning, because he has heard your grumbling against him. Who are we? You are not grumbling against us, but against the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told Aaron, ‘Say to the entire Israelite community, “Come before the Lord, for he has heard your grumbling.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Aaron was speaking to the whole Israelite community, they looked towards the desert, and there was the glory of the Lord appearing in the cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I have heard the grumbling of the Israelites. Tell them, “At twilight you will eat meat, and in the morning you will be filled with bread. Then you will know that I am the Lord your God.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That evening quail came and covered the camp, and in the morning there was a layer of dew around the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the dew was gone, thin flakes like frost on the ground appeared on the desert floor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the Israelites saw it, they said to each other, ‘What is it?’ For they did not know what it was.
Moses said to them, ‘It is the bread the Lord has given you to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord has commanded: “Everyone is to gather as much as they need. Take an omer for each person you have in your tent.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites did as they were told; some gathered much, some little.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when they measured it by the omer, the one who gathered much did not have too much, and the one who gathered little did not have too little. Everyone had gathered just as much as they needed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said to them, ‘No one is to keep any of it until morning.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, some of them paid no attention to Moses; they kept part of it until morning, but it was full of maggots and began to smell. So Moses was angry with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each morning everyone gathered as much as they needed, and when the sun grew hot, it melted away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the sixth day, they gathered twice as much – two omers for each person – and the leaders of the community came and reported this to Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, ‘This is what the Lord commanded: “Tomorrow is to be a day of sabbath rest, a holy sabbath to the Lord. So bake what you want to bake and boil what you want to boil. Save whatever is left and keep it until morning.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they saved it until morning, as Moses commanded, and it did not stink or get maggots in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Eat it today,’ Moses said, ‘because today is a sabbath to the Lord. You will not find any of it on the ground today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six days you are to gather it, but on the seventh day, the Sabbath, there will not be any.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, some of the people went out on the seventh day to gather it, but they found none.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘How long will you refuse to keep my commands and my instructions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bear in mind that the Lord has given you the Sabbath; that is why on the sixth day he gives you bread for two days. Everyone is to stay where they are on the seventh day; no one is to go out.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel called the bread manna. It was white like coriander seed and tasted like wafers made with honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, ‘This is what the Lord has commanded: “Take an omer of manna and keep it for the generations to come, so they can see the bread I gave you to eat in the wilderness when I brought you out of Egypt.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses said to Aaron, ‘Take a jar and put an omer of manna in it. Then place it before the Lord to be kept for the generations to come.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Lord commanded Moses, Aaron put the manna with the tablets of the covenant law, that it might be preserved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites ate manna for forty years, until they came to a land that was settled; they ate manna until they reached the border of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (An omer is one tenth of an ephah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole Israelite community set out from the Desert of Sin, travelling from place to place as the Lord commanded. They camped at Rephidim, but there was no water for the people to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they quarrelled with Moses and said, ‘Give us water to drink.’
Moses replied, ‘Why do you quarrel with me? Why do you put the Lord to the test?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people were thirsty for water there, and they grumbled against Moses. They said, ‘Why did you bring us up out of Egypt to make us and our children and livestock die of thirst?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses cried out to the Lord, ‘What am I to do with these people? They are almost ready to stone me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord answered Moses, ‘Go out in front of the people. Take with you some of the elders of Israel and take in your hand the staff with which you struck the Nile, and go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will stand there before you by the rock at Horeb. Strike the rock, and water will come out of it for the people to drink.’ So Moses did this in the sight of the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he called the place Massah and Meribah because the Israelites quarrelled and because they tested the Lord saying, ‘Is the Lord among us or not?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Amalekites came and attacked the Israelites at Rephidim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to Joshua, ‘Choose some of our men and go out to fight the Amalekites. Tomorrow I will stand on top of the hill with the staff of God in my hands.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua fought the Amalekites as Moses had ordered, and Moses, Aaron and Hur went to the top of the hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As long as Moses held up his hands, the Israelites were winning, but whenever he lowered his hands, the Amalekites were winning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses’ hands grew tired, they took a stone and put it under him and he sat on it. Aaron and Hur held his hands up – one on one side, one on the other – so that his hands remained steady till sunset.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua overcame the Amalekite army with the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Write this on a scroll as something to be remembered and make sure that Joshua hears it, because I will completely blot out the name of Amalek from under heaven.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses built an altar and called it The Lord is my Banner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, ‘Because hands were lifted up against the throne of the Lord, the Lord will be at war against the Amalekites from generation to generation.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jethro, the priest of Midian and father-in-law of Moses, heard of everything God had done for Moses and for his people Israel, and how the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Moses had sent away his wife Zipporah, his father-in-law Jethro received her
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and her two sons. One son was named Gershom, for Moses said, ‘I have become a foreigner in a foreign land’;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the other was named Eliezer, for he said, ‘My father’s God was my helper; he saved me from the sword of Pharaoh.’
