verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, together with Moses’ sons and wife, came to him in the wilderness, where he was camped near the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jethro had sent word to him, ‘I, your father-in-law Jethro, am coming to you with your wife and her two sons.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went out to meet his father-in-law and bowed down and kissed him. They greeted each other and then went into the tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses told his father-in-law about everything the Lord had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for Israel’s sake and about all the hardships they had met along the way and how the Lord had saved them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jethro was delighted to hear about all the good things the Lord had done for Israel in rescuing them from the hand of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, ‘Praise be to the Lord, who rescued you from the hand of the Egyptians and of Pharaoh, and who rescued the people from the hand of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I know that the Lord is greater than all other gods, for he did this to those who had treated Israel arrogantly.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and other sacrifices to God, and Aaron came with all the elders of Israel to eat a meal with Moses’ father-in-law in the presence of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Moses took his seat to serve as judge for the people, and they stood round him from morning till evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his father-in-law saw all that Moses was doing for the people, he said, ‘What is this you are doing for the people? Why do you alone sit as judge, while all these people stand round you from morning till evening?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses answered him, ‘Because the people come to me to seek God’s will.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever they have a dispute, it is brought to me, and I decide between the parties and inform them of God’s decrees and instructions.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses’ father-in-law replied, ‘What you are doing is not good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and these people who come to you will only wear yourselves out. The work is too heavy for you; you cannot handle it alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen now to me and I will give you some advice, and may God be with you. You must be the people’s representative before God and bring their disputes to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Teach them his decrees and instructions, and show them the way they are to live and how they are to behave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But select capable men from all the people – men who fear God, trustworthy men who hate dishonest gain – and appoint them as officials over thousands, hundreds, fifties and tens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let them serve as judges for the people at all times, but let them bring every difficult case to you; the simple cases they can decide themselves. That will make your load lighter, because they will share it with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you do this and God so commands, you will be able to stand the strain, and all these people will go home satisfied.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses listened to his father-in-law and did everything he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He chose capable men from all Israel and made them leaders of the people, officials over thousands, hundreds, fifties and tens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They served as judges for the people at all times. The difficult cases they brought to Moses, but the simple ones they decided themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses sent his father-in-law on his way, and Jethro returned to his own country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day of the third month after the Israelites left Egypt – on that very day – they came to the Desert of Sinai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they set out from Rephidim, they entered the Desert of Sinai, and Israel camped there in the desert in front of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses went up to God, and the Lord called to him from the mountain and said, ‘This is what you are to say to the descendants of Jacob and what you are to tell the people of Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You yourselves have seen what I did to Egypt, and how I carried you on eagles’ wings and brought you to myself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now if you obey me fully and keep my covenant, then out of all nations you will be my treasured possession. Although the whole earth is mine,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you will be for me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation.” These are the words you are to speak to the Israelites.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went back and summoned the elders of the people and set before them all the words the Lord had commanded him to speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people all responded together, ‘We will do everything the Lord has said.’ So Moses brought their answer back to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, ‘I am going to come to you in a dense cloud, so that the people will hear me speaking with you and will always put their trust in you.’ Then Moses told the Lord what the people had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, ‘Go to the people and consecrate them today and tomorrow. Make them wash their clothes
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and be ready by the third day, because on that day the Lord will come down on Mount Sinai in the sight of all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put limits for the people around the mountain and tell them, “Be careful that you do not approach the mountain or touch the foot of it. Whoever touches the mountain is to be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are to be stoned or shot with arrows; not a hand is to be laid on them. No person or animal shall be permitted to live.” Only when the ram’s horn sounds a long blast may they approach the mountain.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Moses had gone down the mountain to the people, he consecrated them, and they washed their clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to the people, ‘Prepare yourselves for the third day. Abstain from sexual relations.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the morning of the third day there was thunder and lightning, with a thick cloud over the mountain, and a very loud trumpet blast. Everyone in the camp trembled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses led the people out of the camp to meet with God, and they stood at the foot of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mount Sinai was covered with smoke, because the Lord descended on it in fire. The smoke billowed up from it like smoke from a furnace, and the whole mountain trembled violently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the sound of the trumpet grew louder and louder, Moses spoke and the voice of God answered him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord descended to the top of Mount Sinai and called Moses to the top of the mountain. So Moses went up
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord said to him, ‘Go down and warn the people so they do not force their way through to see the Lord and many of them perish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even the priests, who approach the Lord, must consecrate themselves, or the Lord will break out against them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to the Lord, ‘The people cannot come up Mount Sinai, because you yourself warned us, “Put limits around the mountain and set it apart as holy.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord replied, ‘Go down and bring Aaron up with you. But the priests and the people must not force their way through to come up to the Lord, or he will break out against them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went down to the people and told them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And God spoke all these words:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You shall have no other gods before me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You shall not make for yourself an image in the form of anything in heaven above or on the earth beneath or in the waters below.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not bow down to them or worship them; for I, the Lord your God, am a jealous God, punishing the children for the sin of the parents to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but showing love to a thousand generations of those who love me and keep my commandments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You shall not misuse the name of the Lord your God, for the Lord will not hold anyone guiltless who misuses his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Remember the Sabbath day by keeping it holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six days you shall labour and do all your work,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the seventh day is a sabbath to the Lord your God. On it you shall not do any work, neither you, nor your son or daughter, nor your male or female servant, nor your animals, nor any foreigner residing in your towns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth, the sea, and all that is in them, but he rested on the seventh day. Therefore the Lord blessed the Sabbath day and made it holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Honour your father and your mother, so that you may live long in the land the Lord your God is giving you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You shall not murder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You shall not commit adultery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You shall not steal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You shall not give false testimony against your neighbour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You shall not covet your neighbour’s house. You shall not covet your neighbour’s wife, or his male or female servant, his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbour.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people saw the thunder and lightning and heard the trumpet and saw the mountain in smoke, they trembled with fear. They stayed at a distance
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to Moses, ‘Speak to us yourself and we will listen. But do not let God speak to us or we will die.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to the people, ‘Do not be afraid. God has come to test you, so that the fear of God will be with you to keep you from sinning.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people remained at a distance, while Moses approached the thick darkness where God was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Tell the Israelites this: “You have seen for yourselves that I have spoken to you from heaven:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: do not make any gods to be alongside me; do not make for yourselves gods of silver or gods of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘“Make an altar of earth for me and sacrifice on it your burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, your sheep and goats and your cattle. Wherever I cause my name to be honoured, I will come to you and bless you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you make an altar of stones for me, do not build it with dressed stones, for you will defile it if you use a tool on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And do not go up to my altar on steps, or your private parts may be exposed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘These are the laws you are to set before them:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If you buy a Hebrew servant, he is to serve you for six years. But in the seventh year, he shall go free, without paying anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he comes alone, he is to go free alone; but if he has a wife when he comes, she is to go with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If his master gives him a wife and she bears him sons or daughters, the woman and her children shall belong to her master, and only the man shall go free.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘But if the servant declares, “I love my master and my wife and children and do not want to go free,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then his master must take him before the judges. He shall take him to the door or the door-post and pierce his ear with an awl. Then he will be his servant for life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If a man sells his daughter as a servant, she is not to go free as male servants do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If she does not please the master who has selected her for himself, he must let her be redeemed. He has no right to sell her to foreigners, because he has broken faith with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he selects her for his son, he must grant her the rights of a daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he marries another woman, he must not deprive the first one of her food, clothing and marital rights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he does not provide her with these three things, she is to go free, without any payment of money.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Anyone who strikes a person with a fatal blow is to be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, if it is not done intentionally, but God lets it happen, they are to flee to a place I will designate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if anyone schemes and kills someone deliberately, that person is to be taken from my altar and put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Anyone who attacks their father or mother is to be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Anyone who kidnaps someone is to be put to death, whether the victim has been sold or is still in the kidnapper’s possession.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Anyone who curses their father or mother is to be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If people quarrel and one person hits another with a stone or with their fist and the victim does not die but is confined to bed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the one who struck the blow will not be held liable if the other can get up and walk around outside with a staff; however, the guilty party must pay the injured person for any loss of time and see that the victim is completely healed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Anyone who beats their male or female slave with a rod must be punished if the slave dies as a direct result,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but they are not to be punished if the slave recovers after a day or two, since the slave is their property.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If people are fighting and hit a pregnant woman and she gives birth prematurely but there is no serious injury, the offender must be fined whatever the woman’s husband demands and the court allows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if there is serious injury, you are to take life for life,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: burn for burn, wound for wound, bruise for bruise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘An owner who hits a male or female slave in the eye and destroys it must let the slave go free to compensate for the eye.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And an owner who knocks out the tooth of a male or female slave must let the slave go free to compensate for the tooth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If a bull gores a man or woman to death, the bull is to be stoned to death, and its meat must not be eaten. But the owner of the bull will not be held responsible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If, however, the bull has had the habit of goring and the owner has been warned but has not kept it penned up and it kills a man or woman, the bull is to be stoned and its owner also is to be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, if payment is demanded, the owner may redeem his life by the payment of whatever is demanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This law also applies if the bull gores a son or a daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the bull gores a male or female slave, the owner must pay thirty shekels of silver to the master of the slave, and the bull is to be stoned to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If anyone uncovers a pit or digs one and fails to cover it and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the one who opened the pit must pay the owner for the loss and take the dead animal in exchange.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If anyone’s bull injures someone else’s bull and it dies, the two parties are to sell the live one and divide both the money and the dead animal equally.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, if it was known that the bull had the habit of goring, yet the owner did not keep it penned up, the owner must pay, animal for animal, and take the dead animal in exchange.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Whoever steals an ox or a sheep and slaughters it or sells it must pay back five head of cattle for the ox and four sheep for the sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If a thief is caught breaking in at night and is struck a fatal blow, the defender is not guilty of bloodshed;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but if it happens after sunrise, the defender is guilty of bloodshed.
‘Anyone who steals must certainly make restitution, but if they have nothing, they must be sold to pay for their theft.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the stolen animal is found alive in their possession – whether ox or donkey or sheep – they must pay back double.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If anyone grazes their livestock in a field or vineyard and lets them stray and they graze in someone else’s field, the offender must make restitution from the best of their own field or vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If a fire breaks out and spreads into thorn-bushes so that it burns sheaves of corn or standing corn or the whole field, the one who started the fire must make restitution.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If anyone gives a neighbour silver or goods for safekeeping and they are stolen from the neighbour’s house, the thief, if caught, must pay back double.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the thief is not found, the owner of the house must appear before the judges, and they must determine whether the owner of the house has laid hands on the other person’s property.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all cases of illegal possession of an ox, a donkey, a sheep, a garment, or any other lost property about which somebody says, “This is mine,” both parties are to bring their cases before the judges. The one whom the judges declare guilty must pay back double to the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If anyone gives a donkey, an ox, a sheep or any other animal to their neighbour for safekeeping and it dies or is injured or is taken away while no one is looking,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the issue between them will be settled by the taking of an oath before the Lord that the neighbour did not lay hands on the other person’s property. The owner is to accept this, and no restitution is required.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the animal was stolen from the neighbour, restitution must be made to the owner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If it was torn to pieces by a wild animal, the neighbour shall bring in the remains as evidence and shall not be required to pay for the torn animal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If anyone borrows an animal from their neighbour and it is injured or dies while the owner is not present, they must make restitution.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the owner is with the animal, the borrower will not have to pay. If the animal was hired, the money paid for the hire covers the loss.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If a man seduces a virgin who is not pledged to be married and sleeps with her, he must pay the bride-price, and she shall be his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If her father absolutely refuses to give her to him, he must still pay the bride-price for virgins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not allow a sorceress to live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Anyone who has sexual relations with an animal is to be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Whoever sacrifices to any god other than the Lord must be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not ill-treat or oppress a foreigner, for you were foreigners in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not take advantage of the widow or the fatherless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you do and they cry out to me, I will certainly hear their cry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My anger will be aroused, and I will kill you with the sword; your wives will become widows and your children fatherless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If you lend money to one of my people among you who is needy, do not treat it like a business deal; charge no interest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you take your neighbour’s cloak as a pledge, return it by sunset,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because that cloak is the only covering your neighbour has. What else can they sleep in? When they cry out to me, I will hear, for I am compassionate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not blaspheme God or curse the ruler of your people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Do not hold back offerings from your granaries or your vats.
‘You must give me the firstborn of your sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do the same with your cattle and your sheep. Let them stay with their mothers for seven days, but give them to me on the eighth day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You are to be my holy people. So do not eat the meat of an animal torn by wild beasts; throw it to the dogs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not spread false reports. Do not help a guilty person by being a malicious witness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not follow the crowd in doing wrong. When you give testimony in a lawsuit, do not pervert justice by siding with the crowd,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and do not show favouritism to a poor person in a lawsuit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If you come across your enemy’s ox or donkey wandering off, be sure to return it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you see the donkey of someone who hates you fallen down under its load, do not leave it there; be sure you help them with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not deny justice to your poor people in their lawsuits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have nothing to do with a false charge and do not put an innocent or honest person to death, for I will not acquit the guilty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not accept a bribe, for a bribe blinds those who see and twists the words of the innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not oppress a foreigner; you yourselves know how it feels to be foreigners, because you were foreigners in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘For six years you are to sow your fields and harvest the crops,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but during the seventh year let the land lie unploughed and unused. Then the poor among your people may get food from it, and the wild animals may eat what is left. Do the same with your vineyard and your olive grove.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Six days do your work, but on the seventh day do not work, so that your ox and your donkey may rest, and so that the slave born in your household and the foreigner living among you may be refreshed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Be careful to do everything I have said to you. Do not invoke the names of other gods; do not let them be heard on your lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Three times a year you are to celebrate a festival to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread; for seven days eat bread made without yeast, as I commanded you. Do this at the appointed time in the month of Aviv, for in that month you came out of Egypt.
‘No one is to appear before me empty-handed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Celebrate the Festival of Harvest with the firstfruits of the crops you sow in your field.
‘Celebrate the Festival of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you gather in your crops from the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Three times a year all the men are to appear before the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Do not offer the blood of a sacrifice to me along with anything containing yeast.
‘The fat of my festival offerings must not be kept until morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Bring the best of the firstfruits of your soil to the house of the Lord your God.
‘Do not cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘See, I am sending an angel ahead of you to guard you along the way and to bring you to the place I have prepared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pay attention to him and listen to what he says. Do not rebel against him; he will not forgive your rebellion, since my Name is in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you listen carefully to what he says and do all that I say, I will be an enemy to your enemies and will oppose those who oppose you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My angel will go ahead of you and bring you into the land of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hivites and Jebusites, and I will wipe them out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not bow down before their gods or worship them or follow their practices. You must demolish them and break their sacred stones to pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Worship the Lord your God, and his blessing will be on your food and water. I will take away disease from among you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and none will miscarry or be barren in your land. I will give you a full life span.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I will send my terror ahead of you and throw into confusion every nation you encounter. I will make all your enemies turn their backs and run.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will send the hornet ahead of you to drive the Hivites, Canaanites and Hittites out of your way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will not drive them out in a single year, because the land would become desolate and the wild animals too numerous for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Little by little I will drive them out before you, until you have increased enough to take possession of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I will establish your borders from the Red Sea to the Mediterranean Sea, and from the desert to the Euphrates River. I will give into your hands the people who live in the land, and you will drive them out before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not make a covenant with them or with their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not let them live in your land or they will cause you to sin against me, because the worship of their gods will certainly be a snare to you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Come up to the Lord, you and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel. You are to worship at a distance,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Moses alone is to approach the Lord; the others must not come near. And the people may not come up with him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses went and told the people all the Lord’s words and laws, they responded with one voice, ‘Everything the Lord has said we will do.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moses then wrote down everything the Lord had said.
He got up early the next morning and built an altar at the foot of the mountain and set up twelve stone pillars representing the twelve tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he sent young Israelite men, and they offered burnt offerings and sacrificed young bulls as fellowship offerings to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses took half of the blood and put it in bowls, and the other half he splashed against the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he took the Book of the Covenant and read it to the people. They responded, ‘We will do everything the Lord has said; we will obey.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses then took the blood, sprinkled it on the people and said, ‘This is the blood of the covenant that the Lord has made with you in accordance with all these words.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and the seventy elders of Israel went up
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and saw the God of Israel. Under his feet was something like a pavement made of lapis lazuli, as bright blue as the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God did not raise his hand against these leaders of the Israelites; they saw God, and they ate and drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, ‘Come up to me on the mountain and stay here, and I will give you the tablets of stone with the law and commandments I have written for their instruction.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses set out with Joshua his assistant, and Moses went up on the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to the elders, ‘Wait here for us until we come back to you. Aaron and Hur are with you, and anyone involved in a dispute can go to them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses went up on the mountain, the cloud covered it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the glory of the Lord settled on Mount Sinai. For six days the cloud covered the mountain, and on the seventh day the Lord called to Moses from within the cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To the Israelites the glory of the Lord looked like a consuming fire on top of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses entered the cloud as he went on up the mountain. And he stayed on the mountain forty days and forty nights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Tell the Israelites to bring me an offering. You are to receive the offering for me from everyone whose heart prompts them to give.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the offerings you are to receive from them: gold, silver and bronze;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: blue, purple and scarlet yarn and fine linen; goat hair;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ram skins dyed red and another type of durable leather; acacia wood;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: olive oil for the light; spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and onyx stones and other gems to be mounted on the ephod and breastpiece.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Then let them make a sanctuary for me, and I will dwell among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make this tabernacle and all its furnishings exactly like the pattern I will show you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Let them make an ark of acacia wood – two and a half cubits long, a cubit and a half wide, and a cubit and a half high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Overlay it with pure gold, both inside and out, and make a gold moulding around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cast four gold rings for it and fasten them to its four feet, with two rings on one side and two rings on the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then make poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Insert the poles into the rings on the sides of the ark to carry it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poles are to remain in the rings of this ark; they are not to be removed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then put in the ark the tablets of the covenant law, which I will give you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make an atonement cover of pure gold – two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And make two cherubim out of hammered gold at the ends of the cover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make one cherub on one end and the second cherub on the other; make the cherubim of one piece with the cover, at the two ends.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cherubim are to have their wings spread upwards, overshadowing the cover with them. The cherubim are to face each other, looking towards the cover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Place the cover on top of the ark and put in the ark the tablets of the covenant law that I will give you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There, above the cover between the two cherubim that are over the ark of the covenant law, I will meet with you and give you all my commands for the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make a table of acacia wood – two cubits long, a cubit wide and a cubit and a half high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Overlay it with pure gold and make a gold moulding around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also make around it a rim a handbreadth wide and put a gold moulding on the rim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make four gold rings for the table and fasten them to the four corners, where the four legs are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rings are to be close to the rim to hold the poles used in carrying the table.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make the poles of acacia wood, overlay them with gold and carry the table with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And make its plates and dishes of pure gold, as well as its pitchers and bowls for the pouring out of offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the bread of the Presence on this table to be before me at all times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make a lampstand of pure gold. Hammer out its base and shaft, and make its flowerlike cups, buds and blossoms of one piece with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six branches are to extend from the sides of the lampstand – three on one side and three on the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three cups shaped like almond flowers with buds and blossoms are to be on one branch, three on the next branch, and the same for all six branches extending from the lampstand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And on the lampstand there are to be four cups shaped like almond flowers with buds and blossoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One bud shall be under the first pair of branches extending from the lampstand, a second bud under the second pair, and a third bud under the third pair – six branches in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The buds and branches shall all be of one piece with the lampstand, hammered out of pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Then make its seven lamps and set them up on it so that they light the space in front of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its wick trimmers and trays are to be of pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A talent of pure gold is to be used for the lampstand and all these accessories.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See that you make them according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make the tabernacle with ten curtains of finely twisted linen and blue, purple and scarlet yarn, with cherubim woven into them by a skilled worker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the curtains are to be the same size – twenty-eight cubits long and four cubits wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Join five of the curtains together, and do the same with the other five.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make loops of blue material along the edge of the end curtain in one set, and do the same with the end curtain in the other set.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make fifty loops on one curtain and fifty loops on the end curtain of the other set, with the loops opposite each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then make fifty gold clasps and use them to fasten the curtains together so that the tabernacle is a unit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make curtains of goat hair for the tent over the tabernacle – eleven altogether.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All eleven curtains are to be the same size – thirty cubits long and four cubits wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Join five of the curtains together into one set and the other six into another set. Fold the sixth curtain double at the front of the tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make fifty loops along the edge of the end curtain in one set and also along the edge of the end curtain in the other set.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then make fifty bronze clasps and put them in the loops to fasten the tent together as a unit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the additional length of the tent curtains, the half curtain that is left over is to hang down at the rear of the tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tent curtains will be a cubit longer on both sides; what is left will hang over the sides of the tabernacle so as to cover it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make for the tent a covering of ram skins dyed red, and over that a covering of other durable leather.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make upright frames of acacia wood for the tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each frame is to be ten cubits long and a cubit and a half wide,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with two projections set parallel to each other. Make all the frames of the tabernacle in this way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make twenty frames for the south side of the tabernacle
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and make forty silver bases to go under them – two bases for each frame, one under each projection.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the other side, the north side of the tabernacle, make twenty frames
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and forty silver bases – two under each frame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make six frames for the far end, that is, the west end of the tabernacle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and make two frames for the corners at the far end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At these two corners they must be double from the bottom all the way to the top and fitted into a single ring; both shall be like that.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So there will be eight frames and sixteen silver bases – two under each frame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Also make crossbars of acacia wood: five for the frames on one side of the tabernacle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: five for those on the other side, and five for the frames on the west, at the far end of the tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The centre crossbar is to extend from end to end at the middle of the frames.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Overlay the frames with gold and make gold rings to hold the crossbars. Also overlay the crossbars with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Set up the tabernacle according to the plan shown you on the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make a curtain of blue, purple and scarlet yarn and finely twisted linen, with cherubim woven into it by a skilled worker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hang it with gold hooks on four posts of acacia wood overlaid with gold and standing on four silver bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hang the curtain from the clasps and place the ark of the covenant law behind the curtain. The curtain will separate the Holy Place from the Most Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the atonement cover on the ark of the covenant law in the Most Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Place the table outside the curtain on the north side of the tabernacle and put the lampstand opposite it on the south side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘For the entrance to the tent make a curtain of blue, purple and scarlet yarn and finely twisted linen – the work of an embroiderer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make gold hooks for this curtain and five posts of acacia wood overlaid with gold. And cast five bronze bases for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Build an altar of acacia wood, three cubits high; it is to be square, five cubits long and five cubits wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make a horn at each of the four corners, so that the horns and the altar are of one piece, and overlay the altar with bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make all its utensils of bronze – its pots to remove the ashes, and its shovels, sprinkling bowls, meat forks and firepans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make a grating for it, a bronze network, and make a bronze ring at each of the four corners of the network.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put it under the ledge of the altar so that it is halfway up the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make poles of acacia wood for the altar and overlay them with bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poles are to be inserted into the rings so they will be on two sides of the altar when it is carried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make the altar hollow, out of boards. It is to be made just as you were shown on the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make a courtyard for the tabernacle. The south side shall be a hundred cubits long and is to have curtains of finely twisted linen,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with twenty posts and twenty bronze bases and with silver hooks and bands on the posts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The north side shall also be a hundred cubits long and is to have curtains, with twenty posts and twenty bronze bases and with silver hooks and bands on the posts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘The west end of the courtyard shall be fifty cubits wide and have curtains, with ten posts and ten bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the east end, towards the sunrise, the courtyard shall also be fifty cubits wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Curtains fifteen cubits long are to be on one side of the entrance, with three posts and three bases,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and curtains fifteen cubits long are to be on the other side, with three posts and three bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘For the entrance to the courtyard, provide a curtain twenty cubits long, of blue, purple and scarlet yarn and finely twisted linen – the work of an embroiderer – with four posts and four bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the posts around the courtyard are to have silver bands and hooks, and bronze bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The courtyard shall be a hundred cubits long and fifty cubits wide, with curtains of finely twisted linen five cubits high, and with bronze bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the other articles used in the service of the tabernacle, whatever their function, including all the tent pegs for it and those for the courtyard, are to be of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Command the Israelites to bring you clear oil of pressed olives for the light so that the lamps may be kept burning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the tent of meeting, outside the curtain that shields the ark of the covenant law, Aaron and his sons are to keep the lamps burning before the Lord from evening till morning. This is to be a lasting ordinance among the Israelites for the generations to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Let Aaron your brother be brought to you from among the Israelites, with his sons Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar, so that they may serve me as priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make sacred garments for your brother Aaron to give him dignity and honour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell all the skilled workers to whom I have given wisdom in such matters that they are to make garments for Aaron, for his consecration, so that he may serve me as priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the garments they are to make: a breastpiece, an ephod, a robe, a woven tunic, a turban and a sash. They are to make these sacred garments for your brother Aaron and his sons, so that they may serve me as priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make them use gold, and blue, purple and scarlet yarn, and fine linen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make the ephod of gold, and of blue, purple and scarlet yarn, and of finely twisted linen – the work of skilled hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to have two shoulder pieces attached to two of its corners, so that it can be fastened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its skilfully woven waistband is to be like it – of one piece with the ephod and made with gold, and with blue, purple and scarlet yarn, and with finely twisted linen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take two onyx stones and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in the order of their birth – six names on one stone and the remaining six on the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Engrave the names of the sons of Israel on the two stones the way a gem cutter engraves a seal. Then mount the stones in gold filigree settings
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and fasten them on the shoulder pieces of the ephod as memorial stones for the sons of Israel. Aaron is to bear the names on his shoulders as a memorial before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make gold filigree settings
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and two braided chains of pure gold, like a rope, and attach the chains to the settings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Fashion a breastpiece for making decisions – the work of skilled hands. Make it like the ephod: of gold, and of blue, purple and scarlet yarn, and of finely twisted linen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to be square – a span long and a span wide – and folded double.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then mount four rows of precious stones on it. The first row shall be carnelian, chrysolite and beryl;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the second row shall be turquoise, lapis lazuli and emerald;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the third row shall be jacinth, agate and amethyst;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the fourth row shall be topaz, onyx and jasper. Mount them in gold filigree settings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There are to be twelve stones, one for each of the names of the sons of Israel, each engraved like a seal with the name of one of the twelve tribes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘For the breastpiece make braided chains of pure gold, like a rope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two gold rings for it and fasten them to two corners of the breastpiece.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fasten the two gold chains to the rings at the corners of the breastpiece,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the other ends of the chains to the two settings, attaching them to the shoulder pieces of the ephod at the front.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two gold rings and attach them to the other two corners of the breastpiece on the inside edge next to the ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two more gold rings and attach them to the bottom of the shoulder pieces on the front of the ephod, close to the seam just above the waistband of the ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rings of the breastpiece are to be tied to the rings of the ephod with blue cord, connecting it to the waistband, so that the breastpiece will not swing out from the ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Whenever Aaron enters the Holy Place, he will bear the names of the sons of Israel over his heart on the breastpiece of decision as a continuing memorial before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also put the Urim and the Thummim in the breastpiece, so they may be over Aaron’s heart whenever he enters the presence of the Lord. Thus Aaron will always bear the means of making decisions for the Israelites over his heart before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make the robe of the ephod entirely of blue cloth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with an opening for the head in its centre. There shall be a woven edge like a collar around this opening, so that it will not tear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make pomegranates of blue, purple and scarlet yarn around the hem of the robe, with gold bells between them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gold bells and the pomegranates are to alternate round the hem of the robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron must wear it when he ministers. The sound of the bells will be heard when he enters the Holy Place before the Lord and when he comes out, so that he will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it as on a seal: holy to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fasten a blue cord to it to attach it to the turban; it is to be on the front of the turban.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will be on Aaron’s forehead, and he will bear the guilt involved in the sacred gifts the Israelites consecrate, whatever their gifts may be. It will be on Aaron’s forehead continually so that they will be acceptable to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Weave the tunic of fine linen and make the turban of fine linen. The sash is to be the work of an embroiderer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make tunics, sashes and caps for Aaron’s sons to give them dignity and honour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After you put these clothes on your brother Aaron and his sons, anoint and ordain them. Consecrate them so they may serve me as priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make linen undergarments as a covering for the body, reaching from the waist to the thigh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Aaron and his sons must wear them whenever they enter the tent of meeting or approach the altar to minister in the Holy Place, so that they will not incur guilt and die.
‘This is to be a lasting ordinance for Aaron and his descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what you are to do to consecrate them, so that they may serve me as priests: take a young bull and two rams without defect.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And from the finest wheat flour make round loaves without yeast, thick loaves without yeast and with olive oil mixed in, and thin loaves without yeast and brushed with olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put them in a basket and present them in it – along with the bull and the two rams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then bring Aaron and his sons to the entrance to the tent of meeting and wash them with water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take the garments and dress Aaron with the tunic, the robe of the ephod, the ephod itself and the breastpiece. Fasten the ephod on him by its skilfully woven waistband.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the turban on his head and attach the sacred emblem to the turban.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take the anointing oil and anoint him by pouring it on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring his sons and dress them in tunics
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and fasten caps on them. Then tie sashes on Aaron and his sons. The priesthood is theirs by a lasting ordinance.
‘Then you shall ordain Aaron and his sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Bring the bull to the front of the tent of meeting, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Slaughter it in the Lord’s presence at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take some of the bull’s blood and put it on the horns of the altar with your finger, and pour out the rest of it at the base of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take all the fat on the internal organs, the covering of the liver, and both kidneys with the fat on them, and burn them on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But burn the bull’s flesh and its hide and its intestines outside the camp. It is a sin offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take one of the rams, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Slaughter it and take the blood and splash it against the sides of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cut the ram into pieces and wash the internal organs and the legs, putting them with the head and the other pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then burn the entire ram on the altar. It is a burnt offering to the Lord, a pleasing aroma, a food offering presented to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take the other ram, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Slaughter it, take some of its blood and put it on the lobes of the right ears of Aaron and his sons, on the thumbs of their right hands, and on the big toes of their right feet. Then splash blood against the sides of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And take some of the blood on the altar and some of the anointing oil and sprinkle it on Aaron and his garments and on his sons and their garments. Then he and his sons and their garments will be consecrated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take from this ram the fat, the fat tail, the fat on the internal organs, the covering of the liver, both kidneys with the fat on them, and the right thigh. (This is the ram for the ordination.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the basket of bread made without yeast, which is before the Lord, take one round loaf, one thick loaf with olive oil mixed in, and one thin loaf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put all these in the hands of Aaron and his sons and wave them before the Lord as a wave offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take them from their hands and burn them on the altar along with the burnt offering for a pleasing aroma to the Lord, a food offering presented to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After you take the breast of the ram for Aaron’s ordination, wave it before the Lord as a wave offering, and it will be your share.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Consecrate those parts of the ordination ram that belong to Aaron and his sons: the breast that was waved and the thigh that was presented.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is always to be the regular share from the Israelites for Aaron and his sons. It is the contribution the Israelites are to make to the Lord from their fellowship offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Aaron’s sacred garments will belong to his descendants so that they can be anointed and ordained in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The son who succeeds him as priest and comes to the tent of meeting to minister in the Holy Place is to wear them seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take the ram for the ordination and cook the meat in a sacred place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the entrance to the tent of meeting, Aaron and his sons are to eat the meat of the ram and the bread that is in the basket.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are to eat these offerings by which atonement was made for their ordination and consecration. But no one else may eat them, because they are sacred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if any of the meat of the ordination ram or any bread is left over till morning, burn it up. It must not be eaten, because it is sacred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do for Aaron and his sons everything I have commanded you, taking seven days to ordain them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sacrifice a bull each day as a sin offering to make atonement. Purify the altar by making atonement for it, and anoint it to consecrate it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days make atonement for the altar and consecrate it. Then the altar will be most holy, and whatever touches it will be holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what you are to offer on the altar regularly each day: two lambs a year old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Offer one in the morning and the other at twilight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the first lamb offer a tenth of an ephah of the finest flour mixed with a quarter of a hin of oil from pressed olives, and a quarter of a hin of wine as a drink offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sacrifice the other lamb at twilight with the same grain offering and its drink offering as in the morning – a pleasing aroma, a food offering presented to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘For the generations to come this burnt offering is to be made regularly at the entrance to the tent of meeting, before the Lord. There I will meet you and speak to you;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: there also I will meet with the Israelites, and the place will be consecrated by my glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘So I will consecrate the tent of meeting and the altar and will consecrate Aaron and his sons to serve me as priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will dwell among the Israelites and be their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will know that I am the Lord their God, who brought them out of Egypt so that I might dwell among them. I am the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make an altar of acacia wood for burning incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to be square, a cubit long and a cubit wide, and two cubits high – its horns of one piece with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Overlay the top and all the sides and the horns with pure gold, and make a gold moulding around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two gold rings for the altar below the moulding – two on each of the opposite sides – to hold the poles used to carry it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the altar in front of the curtain that shields the ark of the covenant law – before the atonement cover that is over the tablets of the covenant law – where I will meet with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Aaron must burn fragrant incense on the altar every morning when he tends the lamps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He must burn incense again when he lights the lamps at twilight so that incense will burn regularly before the Lord for the generations to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not offer on this altar any other incense or any burnt offering or grain offering, and do not pour a drink offering on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once a year Aaron shall make atonement on its horns. This annual atonement must be made with the blood of the atoning sin offering for the generations to come. It is most holy to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘When you take a census of the Israelites to count them, each one must pay the Lord a ransom for his life at the time he is counted. Then no plague will come on them when you number them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each one who crosses over to those already counted is to give a half shekel, according to the sanctuary shekel, which weighs twenty gerahs. This half shekel is an offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All who cross over, those twenty years old or more, are to give an offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rich are not to give more than a half shekel and the poor are not to give less when you make the offering to the Lord to atone for your lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Receive the atonement money from the Israelites and use it for the service of the tent of meeting. It will be a memorial for the Israelites before the Lord, making atonement for your lives.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Make a bronze basin, with its bronze stand, for washing. Place it between the tent of meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron and his sons are to wash their hands and feet with water from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever they enter the tent of meeting, they shall wash with water so that they will not die. Also, when they approach the altar to minister by presenting a food offering to the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they shall wash their hands and feet so that they will not die. This is to be a lasting ordinance for Aaron and his descendants for the generations to come.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Take the following fine spices: 500 shekels of liquid myrrh, half as much (that is, 250 shekels) of fragrant cinnamon, 250 shekels of fragrant calamus,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 500 shekels of cassia – all according to the sanctuary shekel – and a hin of olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make these into a sacred anointing oil, a fragrant blend, the work of a perfumer. It will be the sacred anointing oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then use it to anoint the tent of meeting, the ark of the covenant law,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the table and all its articles, the lampstand and its accessories, the altar of incense,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the altar of burnt offering and all its utensils, and the basin with its stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall consecrate them so they will be most holy, and whatever touches them will be holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Anoint Aaron and his sons and consecrate them so they may serve me as priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to the Israelites, “This is to be my sacred anointing oil for the generations to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not pour it on anyone else’s body and do not make any other oil using the same formula. It is sacred, and you are to consider it sacred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever makes perfume like it and puts it on anyone other than a priest must be cut off from their people.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Take fragrant spices – gum resin, onycha and galbanum – and pure frankincense, all in equal amounts,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and make a fragrant blend of incense, the work of a perfumer. It is to be salted and pure and sacred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Grind some of it to powder and place it in front of the ark of the covenant law in the tent of meeting, where I will meet with you. It shall be most holy to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not make any incense with this formula for yourselves; consider it holy to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever makes incense like it to enjoy its fragrance must be cut off from their people.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘See I have chosen Bezalel son of Uri, the son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I have filled him with the Spirit of God, with wisdom, with understanding, with knowledge and with all kinds of skills –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to make artistic designs for work in gold, silver and bronze,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to cut and set stones, to work in wood, and to engage in all kinds of crafts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, I have appointed Oholiab son of Ahisamak, of the tribe of Dan, to help him. Also I have given ability to all the skilled workers to make everything I have commanded you:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the tent of meeting, the ark of the covenant law with the atonement cover on it, and all the other furnishings of the tent –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the table and its articles, the pure gold lampstand and all its accessories, the altar of incense,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the altar of burnt offering and all its utensils, the basin with its stand –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and also the woven garments, both the sacred garments for Aaron the priest and the garments for his sons when they serve as priests,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the anointing oil and fragrant incense for the Holy Place. They are to make them just as I commanded you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Say to the Israelites, “You must observe my Sabbaths. This will be a sign between me and you for the generations to come, so that you may know that I am the Lord, who makes you holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘“Observe the Sabbath, because it is holy to you. Anyone who desecrates it is to be put to death; those who do any work on that day must be cut off from their people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For six days work is to be done, but the seventh day is a day of sabbath rest, holy to the Lord. Whoever does any work on the Sabbath day is to be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites are to observe the Sabbath, celebrating it for the generations to come as a lasting covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will be a sign between me and the Israelites for ever, for in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth, and on the seventh day he rested and was refreshed.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord finished speaking to Moses on Mount Sinai, he gave him the two tablets of the covenant law, the tablets of stone inscribed by the finger of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people saw that Moses was so long in coming down from the mountain, they gathered round Aaron and said, ‘Come, make us gods who will go before us. As for this fellow Moses who brought us up out of Egypt, we don’t know what has happened to him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron answered them, ‘Take off the gold earrings that your wives, your sons and your daughters are wearing, and bring them to me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people took off their earrings and brought them to Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took what they handed him and made it into an idol cast in the shape of a calf, fashioning it with a tool. Then they said, ‘These are your gods, Israel, who brought you up out of Egypt.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Aaron saw this, he built an altar in front of the calf and announced, ‘Tomorrow there will be a festival to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the next day the people rose early and sacrificed burnt offerings and presented fellowship offerings. Afterwards they sat down to eat and drink and got up to indulge in revelry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Go down, because your people, whom you brought up out of Egypt, have become corrupt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have been quick to turn away from what I commanded them and have made themselves an idol cast in the shape of a calf. They have bowed down to it and sacrificed to it and have said, “These are your gods, Israel, who brought you up out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I have seen these people,’ the Lord said to Moses, ‘and they are a stiff-necked people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now leave me alone so that my anger may burn against them and that I may destroy them. Then I will make you into a great nation.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses sought the favour of the Lord his God. ‘Lord,’ he said, ‘why should your anger burn against your people, whom you brought out of Egypt with great power and a mighty hand?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should the Egyptians say, “It was with evil intent that he brought them out, to kill them in the mountains and to wipe them off the face of the earth”? Turn from your fierce anger; relent and do not bring disaster on your people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember your servants Abraham, Isaac and Israel, to whom you swore by your own self: “I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and I will give your descendants all this land I promised them, and it will be their inheritance for ever.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord relented and did not bring on his people the disaster he had threatened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses turned and went down the mountain with the two tablets of the covenant law in his hands. They were inscribed on both sides, front and back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tablets were the work of God; the writing was the writing of God, engraved on the tablets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joshua heard the noise of the people shouting, he said to Moses, ‘There is the sound of war in the camp.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moses replied:
‘It is not the sound of victory,
    it is not the sound of defeat;
    it is the sound of singing that I hear.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses approached the camp and saw the calf and the dancing, his anger burned and he threw the tablets out of his hands, breaking them to pieces at the foot of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he took the calf the people had made and burned it in the fire; then he ground it to powder, scattered it on the water and made the Israelites drink it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to Aaron, ‘What did these people do to you, that you led them into such great sin?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Do not be angry, my lord,’ Aaron answered. ‘You know how prone these people are to evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to me, “Make us gods who will go before us. As for this fellow Moses who brought us up out of Egypt, we don’t know what has happened to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I told them, “Whoever has any gold jewellery, take it off.” Then they gave me the gold, and I threw it into the fire, and out came this calf!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses saw that the people were running wild and that Aaron had let them get out of control and so become a laughing-stock to their enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he stood at the entrance to the camp and said, ‘Whoever is for the Lord, come to me.’ And all the Levites rallied to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to them, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: “Each man strap a sword to his side. Go back and forth through the camp from one end to the other, each killing his brother and friend and neighbour.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites did as Moses commanded, and that day about three thousand of the people died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said, ‘You have been set apart to the Lord today, for you were against your own sons and brothers, and he has blessed you this day.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Moses said to the people, ‘You have committed a great sin. But now I will go up to the Lord; perhaps I can make atonement for your sin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went back to the Lord and said, ‘Oh, what a great sin these people have committed! They have made themselves gods of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, please forgive their sin – but if not, then blot me out of the book you have written.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord replied to Moses, ‘Whoever has sinned against me I will blot out of my book.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go, lead the people to the place I spoke of, and my angel will go before you. However, when the time comes for me to punish, I will punish them for their sin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord struck the people with a plague because of what they did with the calf Aaron had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, ‘Leave this place, you and the people you brought up out of Egypt, and go up to the land I promised on oath to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, saying, “I will give it to your descendants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will send an angel before you and drive out the Canaanites, Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go up to the land flowing with milk and honey. But I will not go with you, because you are a stiff-necked people and I might destroy you on the way.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people heard these distressing words, they began to mourn and no one put on any ornaments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord had said to Moses, ‘Tell the Israelites, “You are a stiff-necked people. If I were to go with you even for a moment, I might destroy you. Now take off your ornaments and I will decide what to do with you.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelites stripped off their ornaments at Mount Horeb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Moses used to take a tent and pitch it outside the camp some distance away, calling it the ‘tent of meeting’. Anyone enquiring of the Lord would go to the tent of meeting outside the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And whenever Moses went out to the tent, all the people rose and stood at the entrances to their tents, watching Moses until he entered the tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Moses went into the tent, the pillar of cloud would come down and stay at the entrance, while the Lord spoke with Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the people saw the pillar of cloud standing at the entrance to the tent, they all stood and worshipped, each at the entrance to their tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord would speak to Moses face to face, as one speaks to a friend. Then Moses would return to the camp, but his young assistant Joshua son of Nun did not leave the tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to the Lord, ‘You have been telling me, “Lead these people,” but you have not let me know whom you will send with me. You have said, “I know you by name and you have found favour with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you are pleased with me, teach me your ways so I may know you and continue to find favour with you. Remember that this nation is your people.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord replied, ‘My Presence will go with you, and I will give you rest.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said to him, ‘If your Presence does not go with us, do not send us up from here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How will anyone know that you are pleased with me and with your people unless you go with us? What else will distinguish me and your people from all the other people on the face of the earth?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, ‘I will do the very thing you have asked, because I am pleased with you and I know you by name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said, ‘Now show me your glory.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said, ‘I will cause all my goodness to pass in front of you, and I will proclaim my name, the Lord, in your presence. I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But,’ he said, ‘you cannot see my face, for no one may see me and live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said, ‘There is a place near me where you may stand on a rock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When my glory passes by, I will put you in a cleft in the rock and cover you with my hand until I have passed by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will remove my hand and you will see my back; but my face must not be seen.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, ‘Chisel out two stone tablets like the first ones, and I will write on them the words that were on the first tablets, which you broke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be ready in the morning, and then come up on Mount Sinai. Present yourself to me there on top of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one is to come with you or be seen anywhere on the mountain; not even the flocks and herds may graze in front of the mountain.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses chiselled out two stone tablets like the first ones and went up Mount Sinai early in the morning, as the Lord had commanded him; and he carried the two stone tablets in his hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord came down in the cloud and stood there with him and proclaimed his name, the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he passed in front of Moses, proclaiming, ‘The Lord, the Lord, the compassionate and gracious God, slow to anger, abounding in love and faithfulness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: maintaining love to thousands, and forgiving wickedness, rebellion and sin. Yet he does not leave the guilty unpunished; he punishes the children and their children for the sin of the parents to the third and fourth generation.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses bowed to the ground at once and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator
